rename.from: [BUG] Classifiers failing `fit` when not enough time points
rename.to: [BUG] Four classifiers failing `fit` when not enough time points (10)

body:
to recreate 
train_X = np.random.rand(10,10)
train_y = np.random.randint(low=0, high=2, size=10)
print(train_y)
drcif = DrCIF()
drcif.fit(train_X, train_y)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9594042/149024240-8e1660b1-e927-427c-91a9-158b13414504.png)

@MatthewMiddlehurst len_range - _min_interval[r] is coming out as zero. I think we probably just need to put a data check at the start of _fit, I dont think we have ever tried with series length of 10 before

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9594042/149024594-8464d458-5f83-4b6f-86e0-26b27c62efda.png)
len_range = 5, min_intervals = 4, so random fails. It may just need an edge case check,  
                    len_range = min(
                        transform_length - intervals[j][0],
                        self._max_interval[r],
                    )

>where are the methods _make_panel_X and _make_Y?

Ah, sorry, forgot the imports. Added them at the top.

& `MUSE` seems to have stochastic failures even for larger sizes?
See this run
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/runs/4783434797?check_suite_focus=true

Locally, the test was not failing.

issue.title: [ENH] Test refactor with scenarios

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
PR that uses scenarios from #1819 for refactoring and simplifying the tests.

Main rationale for this refactor:
* the previous test suite was unable to run estimators through multiple input data scenarios without a lot of manual coding. This is now "slot in" via adding one more scenario in scenario config files.
* this was needed to ensure reliable testing in two major development directions: transformers refactor (#1854), and hierarchical forecasting (#1818), since in both we decided with polymorphic inputs, i.e., estimators that can be used to `fit` and `predict`/`transform` both `Series` and `Panel` data. The previous test suite was able to test only one kind of input per estimator type.
* the previous test suite relied a lot on if/else chains and for-loops for dispatch and iteration. The refactur result is more extensible and follows the open/closed principle better, in that scenarios and entire test modules are easier to add.

Refactoring is carried out for `test_all_estimators` only, which signposts how the refactor for remaining tests would look like.
The high-level structure is as follows:

* tests now rely additionaly rely on an additional type of fixture, "scenarios", which encode data that is passed to estimators, and methods that are sequentially called. Having multiple scenarios allow to test multiple sequences of data being passed as a formulaic test case across estimators, e.g., "passing `fh` in `fit` and no `X`" or "passing `fh` only in `predict` and `X` and `y` that is multivariate". See `_utils.testing.scenarios`. Uses #1819 (scenarios)
* not all scenarios are applicable to all estimators (e.g., classifiers need `X` and `y` to be Panel/vector; some forecasters must be given `fh` in `fit`), hence this is reliant on some machinery to generate fixture combinations, namely estimator/scenario combinations. See `tests.test_all_estimators.pytest_generate_tests`. Uses #1839 (conditional fixture generation).
* in the process of slightly more stringent testing, some bugs were discovered in individual estimators, which are being fixed as far it requires for the refactor to run. See #1846.
* The test suite currently runs only 1:1 remaps of "pre-refactor" tests, while containing more scenarios. These could be run as well, but would cause a lot more estimators to fail, since these are scenarios that weren't stringently tested before. The larger set of scenarios can be easily switched on and off, by controlling how the `pre-refactor` tag oof scenarios is handled.

Conditional on PRs
* test scenarios in #1819
* the conditional fixture plugin for `pytest` in #1839
* #1838 for retrieving scenarios applicable to specific estimators
* extended `deep_equals` in #1844 for making nested equality comparisons
* bugfixes in #1846 uncovered by more rigorous testing

After this, the next step would be to wrap entire testing suites in classes. This will allow easy inheritance across modules, a "one-stop-function" to test new estimators with, and usage of the test suite in third party packages.

The tests all pass, but this includes a few new escapes:

* `STLTransformer`, `STLforecaster`, and `ConditionalDeseasonalizer`, due to ongoing, unresolved discussion on #1677, #1773
* `StackingForecaster` on `test_predict_time_index_with_X`. Funny things seem to happen if `X` is passed, of unclear cause so far.
* `MUSE`, seems to fail stochastically with higher probabiltiy on smaller data sets, see #1866 for `MUSE` and other classifiers which appear to fail deterministically on too small data sets (the latter are not escaped, since the scenarios have now been chosen to have large enough data to get around this).

body: not sure about MUSE, will try fix our two first then take a look at the other two.

train_X = np.random.rand(10, 10)
#val = np.random.randint(low=0, high=1)
#print(val)
train_y = np.random.randint(low=0, high=2, size = 10)
cls = MUSE()
cls.fit(train_X, train_y)

gives an intermittent error

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9594042/149148860-dc628a73-f52a-4560-b12b-d999a3e6d731.png)

looks to be a problem with the data not being consistent with logistic regression (assuming this is what linear_models\_logistic.py is). I'll take a look

so its getting to here in _muse and all_words is empty. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9594042/149149613-098f9b4e-a189-46ae-9d84-42297e5579a2.png)

basically feature selection finds no relevant words, which causes the sklearn classifier to (iunderstandably) crash. Discussed with Matt and we will add a special case for when all_words is empty and just keep all the words, any thoughts @patrickzib ?
and @MatthewMiddlehurst has also found the problem with DrCIF and by implication HC2, PR to follow.
one way would be fallback behaviour. For instances, if whatever features fail to extract, predict the majority class on the training set instead of running against a wall.
